Feature Stub

Recent:

Day 55 - Trello's Homepage

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Trello strips away all of their homepage content to a single pair of CTAs. When you’re logged in, it gives you the message “Hey, you’re logged in! Go to your boards.”

Why it’s good: Designing websites that allow logins are a fundamentally different task than more static sites. Every time you make a content decision, you have to ask “Is this right for both audiences?”

What’s so clever about this is subtle. You’ll notice that there’s a difference between the URLs because Trello.com automatically redirects you to your boards when you’re logged in. They know that you still might find your way to this homepage somehow, so they give you a simple and friendly way to get back. Thanks guys.

Day 54 - Tic Tag Toe

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Tic TAG Toe is a tagging game from Reading Stats in your Pocket, a third party app that tells statistics about your Pocket Queue. It presents you five random items from your queue, and has you select tags for them.

Why it’s good: What sort of behavior do you want to encourage in your users? This app needs some polish, but the goal is brilliant. I have somewhere in the neighborhood of 1,000 items currently in my Pocket queue. The majority of them don’t have tags. I’ve spent time going through and tagging items in order, but it just feels like a drag. Bleh. No thanks.

This little feature is great because it’s just 5 items! That will take just a minute, right? It escorts you 5 random untagged items in your queue, and suggests some tags or lets you pick your own. It then encourages you to go for another round. Even if the execution could be improved, the idea itself is a solid example of managing complexity for the user.

Day 53 - YNAB'S Email Newsletter

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: YNAB is relaunching their newsletter. This is the email they sent me to tell me about it.

Why it’s good: The language used through this entire piece is so carefully crafted. It’s conversational and fun. It’s interesting, and drives you towards the goal, signing up for the new newsletter.

It’s my belief that there’s a special circle in hell for people who grab my email from another list and start spamming me, so I especially appreciate the secondary sign up.

Day 52 - Dimming Light Switch

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: This is a light dimmer that looks just like a normal light switch. Seems pretty mundane.

Why it’s good: This interface is so fantastic because it uses a familiar form factor and just adds in a new element. Let’s pretend you don’t know what a light dimmer is and you’re afraid to experiment. You still have the ability to use this like a normal light switch.

Often when we are developing new interfaces, we want to make something completely bespoke and custom. However, it’s so much better to reference the things that our users already know and understand. We don’t have to be limited by what already exists, but extending the uses of existing interfaces (instead of doing a complete redesign) helps meet users where they are, whether they are experts or beginners.

Day 51 - Google Fit's Celebration

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When you hit step goal in Google Fit, it celebrates by sending you a notification. When you load it up, it counts your steps and then gives you a little firework (with a little horn sound!)

Why it’s good: I admit to a high level of skepticism when it comes health tracking apps and changing behavior. It’s not fun to be shamed into walking more, so celebrating the successes are important.

I don’t hit the goal all that frequently. The times that I do, it’s worth some celebration! By contrast, I’ve gotten an email every week from Moto Fit that begins with “Everyone has an off week” - mainly because I don’t wear my watch on Saturdays or Sundays (so it thinks that I lie in bed all day or something.) The fanfare matches how I feel about it, so it’s a great time to show a little flair.
